paragraphs.body: In the ${link_0}, names are drawn from a wide variety of languages and sources. Although many names are transliterated into Chinese characters, the form of ${link_1} used in Avatar, most names are not Chinese, and are either derived from other languages or completely fictional.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: In the World of Avatar, names are drawn from a wide variety of languages and sources. Although many names are transliterated into Chinese characters, the form of writing used in Avatar, most names are not Chinese, and are either derived from other languages or completely fictional.

paragraphs.body: The format of this list of name translations is: Name - Traditional Hanzi (simplified Hanzi if different) - Mandarin Pronunciation in Hanyu Pinyin/Pronunciation in other languages - English translation. Because many characters' names are never seen written on screen, and it is impossible to guess the correct characters to write a name without knowing its meaning, Chinese characters may not be given for all names.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: The format of this list of name translations is: Name - Traditional Hanzi (simplified Hanzi if different) - Mandarin Pronunciation in Hanyu Pinyin/Pronunciation in other languages - English translation. Because many characters' names are never seen written on screen, and it is impossible to guess the correct characters to write a name without knowing its meaning, Chinese characters may not be given for all names.

paragraphs.body: A note on East Asian names: Personal names in China, Korea, and Vietnam are usually one or two characters chosen to have an auspicious meaning, while given names in Japanese can sometimes be three. Surnames always come before the given name; in China, Korea, and Vietnam, they are almost always one character, but may be two in Japan.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: A note on East Asian names: Personal names in China, Korea, and Vietnam are usually one or two characters chosen to have an auspicious meaning, while given names in Japanese can sometimes be three. Surnames always come before the given name; in China, Korea, and Vietnam, they are almost always one character, but may be two in Japan.

paragraphs.body: Readers should also note that the simplified characters in the translations on this page – the characters in brackets – are not used in the show. They are merely used as a reference for those unable to read traditional Chinese characters.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Readers should also note that the simplified characters in the translations on this page – the characters in brackets – are not used in the show. They are merely used as a reference for those unable to read traditional Chinese characters.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 安昂 – Peaceful soaring.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Aang: 安昂 – Peaceful soaring.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 卡塔拉 – Probably phonetic. Characters mean "block", "pagoda" and "pull".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Katara: 卡塔拉 – Probably phonetic. Characters mean "block", "pagoda" and "pull".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 索卡 – Probably phonetic. Characters mean "inquire" and "block".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Sokka: 索卡 – Probably phonetic. Characters mean "inquire" and "block".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 北方拓芙  - Surname means "North region" and given name means "expanding hibiscus mutabilis" or "expanding lotus". In "Tales of Ba Sing Se", her name is written on the title card as 托夫, meaning "entrusted man", likely due to an error.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Toph Beifong: 北方拓芙  - Surname means "North region" and given name means "expanding hibiscus mutabilis" or "expanding lotus". In "Tales of Ba Sing Se", her name is written on the title card as 托夫, meaning "entrusted man", likely due to an error.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 蘇科(苏科) – Awaken rank. On his wanted poster, his name was written with the characters 祖寇, meaning "ancestor robber". In Ursa's letter to Ikem, Zuko's name was written with the characters 豎髙 meaning "vertical high" with the second character being a variant of "高".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Zuko: 蘇科(苏科) – Awaken rank. On his wanted poster, his name was written with the characters 祖寇, meaning "ancestor robber". In Ursa's letter to Ikem, Zuko's name was written with the characters 豎髙 meaning "vertical high" with the second character being a variant of "高".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 艾洛 – Probably phonetic. The first character means "Chinese mugwort", a type of flower used in a form of traditional Chinese medicine called moxibustion, which is not usually used to name males, and the second character is the name of a river in China.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Iroh: 艾洛 – Probably phonetic. The first character means "Chinese mugwort", a type of flower used in a form of traditional Chinese medicine called moxibustion, which is not usually used to name males, and the second character is the name of a river in China.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 阿柏 – Probably phonetic. The latter character means "cypress".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Appa: 阿柏 – Probably phonetic. The latter character means "cypress".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 模模 - Transliteration of Japanese word "momo", meaning "peach"; used as a common pet name in Japan. Characters mean "imitate".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Momo: 模模 - Transliteration of Japanese word "momo", meaning "peach"; used as a common pet name in Japan. Characters mean "imitate".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: རྒྱ་མཚོ། – "ocean" in Tibetan, sometimes implying "ocean of wisdom," and a common name. It is included as one of the titles given to a number of Dalai Lamas, including the XIV Dalai Lama.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Gyatso: རྒྱ་མཚོ། – "ocean" in Tibetan, sometimes implying "ocean of wisdom," and a common name. It is included as one of the titles given to a number of Dalai Lamas, including the XIV Dalai Lama.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: པ་སངས། – Venus; Friday; also a Tibetan name meaning "born on Friday."
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Pasang: པ་སངས། – Venus; Friday; also a Tibetan name meaning "born on Friday."

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: བཀྲ་ཤིས། – Tibetan name meaning "good fortune/auspiciousness."
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Tashi: བཀྲ་ཤིས། – Tibetan name meaning "good fortune/auspiciousness."

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: དབྱངས་ཅན། - Tibetan translation of the Sanskrit "Saraswati," Goddess of learning and music. Lit. "melodious"
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Yangchen: དབྱངས་ཅན། - Tibetan translation of the Sanskrit "Saraswati," Goddess of learning and music. Lit. "melodious"

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 月 – Moon.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Yue: 月 – Moon.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 布米 – 'Bhumi' means "earth" in Sanskrit. Many northern Indian languages derived from Sanskrit, as well as in Indonesian and Malay. The Chinese characters used for transliteration mean "to spread rice".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Bumi: 布米 – 'Bhumi' means "earth" in Sanskrit. Many northern Indian languages derived from Sanskrit, as well as in Indonesian and Malay. The Chinese characters used for transliteration mean "to spread rice".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 秦 – Qin was the surname of controversial emperor Qin Shi Huang, who unified China. It referred to the state he ruled prior to conquering the rest of China.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Chin: 秦 – Qin was the surname of controversial emperor Qin Shi Huang, who unified China. It referred to the state he ruled prior to conquering the rest of China.

paragraphs.body: Hong Lee (Zuko): 洪禮 (洪礼) – Hong is a traditional Chinese surname meaning "vast" or "deluge"; Lee references the Confucian virtue li, meaning "propriety" or "ritual". He may be named for Li Hong, one of the series' early concept artists.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Hong Lee (Zuko): 洪禮 (洪礼) – Hong is a traditional Chinese surname meaning "vast" or "deluge"; Lee references the Confucian virtue li, meaning "propriety" or "ritual". He may be named for Li Hong, one of the series' early concept artists.

paragraphs.body: Hong Mushi (Iroh): 洪慕士 – Hong is a traditional Chinese surname meaning "vast" or "deluge"; Mushi means "to want to become a scholar".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Hong Mushi (Iroh): 洪慕士 – Hong is a traditional Chinese surname meaning "vast" or "deluge"; Mushi means "to want to become a scholar".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 虛子 – Japanese, meaning "empty child"; this was the pen name of the famous Japanese poet Takahama Kiyoshi.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Kyoshi: 虛子 – Japanese, meaning "empty child"; this was the pen name of the famous Japanese poet Takahama Kiyoshi.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 龍鳳 (龙凤) – Dragon Phoenix. In Chinese tradition, the dragon and phoenix represented the royal throne.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Long Feng: 龍鳳 (龙凤) – Dragon Phoenix. In Chinese tradition, the dragon and phoenix represented the royal throne.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0} – Named after Avatar writer ${link_1}.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Macmu-Ling – Named after Avatar writer Lauren MacMullan.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 美雪 – Common Japanese girl's name meaning "beautiful snow". Named after storyboard artist Miyuki Hoshikawa.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Miyuki: 美雪 – Common Japanese girl's name meaning "beautiful snow". Named after storyboard artist Miyuki Hoshikawa.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 吳 - Korean: O - Oh (Wu in Chinese) is a common surname in Korea, referring to the ancient Kingdom of Wu in China. Named after animator Seung-Hyun Oh.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Oh: 吳 - Korean: O - Oh (Wu in Chinese) is a common surname in Korea, referring to the ancient Kingdom of Wu in China. Named after animator Seung-Hyun Oh.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 奧瑪 (奥玛) – Characters mean "obscure" and "carnelian".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Oma: 奧瑪 (奥玛) – Characters mean "obscure" and "carnelian".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 親父 - Japanese informal term for "dad" or "old man". The first character is Chinese for "parent", with the second being a formal term of respect for an elderly man.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Oyaji: 親父 - Japanese informal term for "dad" or "old man". The first character is Chinese for "parent", with the second being a formal term of respect for an elderly man.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 包 – Bao is a traditional Chinese surname meaning "To cover". It is a pun of the character 泡 (pāo), meaning to boil tea.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Pao: 包 – Bao is a traditional Chinese surname meaning "To cover". It is a pun of the character 泡 (pāo), meaning to boil tea.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 乓 – An abortive pun on the word ping-pong; originally, Aang was going to have another neighbor named Ping, who was cut from the script. The Chinese Characters for ping-pong are simply an onomatopoeia for the sound the ball makes.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Pong: 乓 – An abortive pun on the word ping-pong; originally, Aang was going to have another neighbor named Ping, who was cut from the script. The Chinese Characters for ping-pong are simply an onomatopoeia for the sound the ball makes.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 浦安添 - Cantonese: pu on tim - Pu is a traditional Chinese surname meaning "beach"; On-Tim means "Increasing Peace". Named after Avatar writer ${link_1}.

paragraphs.text: Pu-on Tim: 浦安添 - Cantonese: pu on tim - Pu is a traditional Chinese surname meaning "beach"; On-Tim means "Increasing Peace". Named after Avatar writer Tim Hedrick.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 燃 and 燒 – Ran means "burn" or "ignite" in Chinese. Shaw, more correctly "Shao", means "burn" or "braze". The characters can also be used together to mean "combustion", "flaming", or "kindle".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Ran and Shaw: 燃 and 燒 – Ran means "burn" or "ignite" in Chinese. Shaw, more correctly "Shao", means "burn" or "braze". The characters can also be used together to mean "combustion", "flaming", or "kindle".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 佐藤麻美 – Japanese: Asami is a female name meaning "hemp beauty". Sato is the most common Japanese surname.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0} 愽林 – Characters mean "abundant" and "forest".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Bolin 愽林 – Characters mean "abundant" and "forest".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: Surname (北方) means "north region". While it is unusual for her to have taken her mother's surname, it is not unprecedented; in Japan, for example, if a family had no male heir to carry on its name, it would sometimes adopt the daughter's son-in-law in order to ensure the survival of their name.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Lin Beifong: Surname (北方) means "north region". While it is unusual for her to have taken her mother's surname, it is not unprecedented; in Japan, for example, if a family had no male heir to carry on its name, it would sometimes adopt the daughter's son-in-law in order to ensure the survival of their name.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 柯拉 – From the name Cora, Celtic and Greek for "maiden". She is named after the ${link_1} of the owner of a hotel in Alberta, Canada. On the wanted poster issued by the ${link_2}, her name was written with the characters 寇拉, meaning "bandit drag".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Korra: 柯拉 – From the name Cora, Celtic and Greek for "maiden". She is named after the dog of the owner of a hotel in Alberta, Canada. On the wanted poster issued by the Earth Queen, her name was written with the characters 寇拉, meaning "bandit drag".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 馬高(马高) - Abbreviated version of the Japanese name Makoto, meaning "faithfulness" or "trust". He is named as a tribute to ${link_1}, ${link_2}'s voice actor in the original series. The Chinese characters used to transliterate it mean "horse" and "high".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Mako: 馬高(马高) - Abbreviated version of the Japanese name Makoto, meaning "faithfulness" or "trust". He is named as a tribute to Mako Iwamatsu, Iroh's voice actor in the original series. The Chinese characters used to transliterate it mean "horse" and "high".

paragraphs.body: Noatak: (Inuit: nautaag) – Inland river. Name of village in Alaska.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Noatak: (Inuit: nautaag) – Inland river. Name of village in Alaska.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: བསྟན་འཛིན – Meaning "upholder of the Dharma" or "defender of the faith", it is one of the given names of the XIV Dalai Lama.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Tenzin: བསྟན་འཛིན – Meaning "upholder of the Dharma" or "defender of the faith", it is one of the given names of the XIV Dalai Lama.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0} - Likely named after Ginger Rogers, a popular American actress and dancer of the 1930s.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: (Japanese) – Hiroshi is a common male Japanese name with many meanings depending on the characters used. Sato (佐藤, Satō) is the most common Japanese surname.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 老甘藍 – The characters of his name translate to "old" (often used as a title of respect for an older man) and "wild cabbage"; his name could therefore be translated as "Old Man Cabbage". Lau, written with different characters, is also a common Chinese surname.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Lau Gan-Lan: 老甘藍 – The characters of his name translate to "old" (often used as a title of respect for an older man) and "wild cabbage"; his name could therefore be translated as "Old Man Cabbage". Lau, written with different characters, is also a common Chinese surname.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: (Japanese) – Shiro is a Japanese name that usually means "fourth child", though it can be written with a number of kanji. Shinobi (忍び) is a Japanese word that means "sneak", "thief", or "ninja".
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Shiro Shinobi: (Japanese) – Shiro is a Japanese name that usually means "fourth child", though it can be written with a number of kanji. Shinobi (忍び) is a Japanese word that means "sneak", "thief", or "ninja".

paragraphs.text: Baatar: Баатар – Mongolian word meaning "hero".

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 류 – Ryu is the English transcription of four different rare Korean surnames as well as Japanese for "dragon". He is named after animator ${link_1}.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Ryu: 류 – Ryu is the English transcription of four different rare Korean surnames as well as Japanese for "dragon". He is named after animator Ki Hyun Ryu.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: オタク – Derogatory Japanese term referring to someone with an obsessive interest, usually in anime or manga.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: रोहण – Saskrit name meaning "to ascend; to rise; to attain great heights". Named after ${link_1}'s Indian nephew.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Rohan: रोहण – Saskrit name meaning "to ascend; to rise; to attain great heights". Named after Bryan Konietzko's Indian nephew.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}: 戴笠 - The Dai Li's name has two meanings in Chinese, the first being literal. Dai (戴) means "to wear". Li (笠) is the cone shaped rain hat that farmers and fishermen wear in China, which look similar to the hats worn by Dai Li in the show. However, the same characters are also the name of a person, and it was from him the Dai Li were named. Lieutenant General Dai Li was a top Chinese government official during the first half of 20th century and one of the most feared men in China. He was, infamously, the leader of Chiang Kai-Shek's secret police and the paramilitary fascist Blue Shirt Society. The number of agents in his organization is said to have been over 50,000 at one point, and their assignments included surveillance, kidnapping, apprehension, and assassination. It was because of his "legacy" of oppression that the creators chose to name Ba Sing Se's secret police after him.
section: Names in the World of Avatar
paragraphs.text: Dai Li: 戴笠 - The Dai Li's name has two meanings in Chinese, the first being literal. Dai (戴) means "to wear". Li (笠) is the cone shaped rain hat that farmers and fishermen wear in China, which look similar to the hats worn by Dai Li in the show. However, the same characters are also the name of a person, and it was from him the Dai Li were named. Lieutenant General Dai Li was a top Chinese government official during the first half of 20th century and one of the most feared men in China. He was, infamously, the leader of Chiang Kai-Shek's secret police and the paramilitary fascist Blue Shirt Society. The number of agents in his organization is said to have been over 50,000 at one point, and their assignments included surveillance, kidnapping, apprehension, and assassination. It was because of his "legacy" of oppression that the creators chose to name Ba Sing Se's secret police after him.
